opportunities.structural_shift: CPA shortage (75% retiring) colliding with 70% of SMBs unserved. AI accounting growing 44% CAGR. Nash equilibrium in accounting profession about to break.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI-First SMB Accounting Service
business_models_constructed.target_customer: US small businesses ($100K-$5M revenue) currently doing own books or using basic software. 23M potential customers.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Complete bookkeeping, tax prep, and financial reporting at $99-299/month vs. $2K-10K/year for a CPA. AI handles 90% of work; licensed CPA reviews quarterly.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference: $2-5/client/month. CPA oversight (1 CPA per 200 clients): $15-25/client/month. Infrastructure: $3-5/client/month. Total: $20-35/client/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription tiered by complexity
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x (serving the 70% currently unserved)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $120B+ (current US accounting services ~$160B * 3x Jevons * capture rate)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: CPA licensing integration, data flywheel from millions of transactions, compliance track record, trust through CPA review layer

business_models_constructed.model_name: Fractional AI CFO for Growth SMBs
business_models_constructed.target_customer: SMBs with $500K-$20M revenue that cannot afford a full-time or traditional fractional CFO ($5K-15K/month). 2M+ potential customers.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI-powered financial forecasting, cash flow management, and strategic reporting with human CFO judgment for key decisions. $500-2000/month vs. $5K-15K for traditional fractional CFO.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference + dashboards: $10-20/client/month. Human CFO time (1hr/month per client, 1 CFO per 40 clients): $100-200/client/month. Total: $110-220/client/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription + percentage of identified savings
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 5-8x (80%+ of SMBs currently have no CFO function)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $50B+ (fractional CFO market ~$10B * 5x Jevons expansion)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Proprietary financial data across thousands of SMBs = benchmarking moat. AI improves with each client. Switching costs increase over time.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Tax Preparation for LATAM-US Businesses
business_models_constructed.target_customer: US-LATAM businesses (150K+ companies operating cross-border) needing bilingual tax/compliance. Currently paying $5K-20K/year for cross-border CPA.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Bilingual AI tax/compliance service handling US + LATAM tax obligations at 60-80% lower cost. Spanish-first customer experience.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference: $5-10/client/month. Bilingual CPA oversight: $25-50/client/month. Total: $30-60/client/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription + per-filing fees
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (many cross-border businesses under-compliant due to cost)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $15B (cross-border tax/compliance ~$5B * 3x Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Bilingual AI training data, cross-border regulatory expertise, founder language advantage

assumptions: AI handles 90% of standard bookkeeping accurately
1 CPA can review 200 accounts
Client acquisition cost $200-500

incumbent_analysis.notes: Intuit has AI capabilities but TurboTax model is self-service, not full-service. CPA firms structurally stuck: partner model, billable hours, aging workforce. Gap exists for 'AI-first full-service at self-service price'.

regulatory_landscape.acquisition_path: Acquire small CPA practice ($50K-$200K) for licensing umbrella. Or partner with licensed CPAs.
regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: Licensed operation locks out pure-tech competitors

confirmed: CPA shortage is real and worsening: 75% approaching retirement, enrollment declining (Thomson Reuters)
70% of SMBs don't use CPAs due to cost (BLS/PYMNTS)
AI can handle standard bookkeeping and tax prep: multiple products in market (Deduction, etc.)
AI accounting market growing 44%+ CAGR (Mordor Intelligence)
likely: SMBs will pay $99-299/month for AI accounting service: similar pricing works for QuickBooks Live
1 CPA can oversee 200 AI-managed accounts: based on current hybrid models
Trust barrier lower for SMBs than enterprise: less compliance scrutiny
uncertain: Customer acquisition cost for SMBs: testable with $20K ad spend in 2 months
Churn rate for AI accounting: testable with pilot cohort

barriers.resolution_path: Acquire small CPA practice ($50K-200K) for licensing umbrella
CPA review layer + SOC 2 compliance builds trust
Target the unserved 70%, not the served 30%

recommended_next_steps: Build MVP for standard bookkeeping (single-entity, US only)
Acquire or partner with small CPA practice for licensing
Test pricing and acquisition cost with $20K pilot
Build Spanish-language version for LATAM cross-border customers
verdict.reasoning: The largest Jevons expansion opportunity in professional services. 70% of US SMBs are unserved. CPA shortage is structural and worsening. AI accuracy is proven. Multiple entry vectors (direct service, platform for CPAs, cross-border). Founder fit is exceptional.

opportunities.structural_shift: Healthcare: $4.3T market, $1.3T in admin, 500K+ nursing shortfall, decades of Baumol premium. Largest stored disruption energy in US economy.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Healthcare Admin Service (Revenue Cycle + Prior Auth)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Independent physician practices (600K+ in US) and small hospital networks spending $20-40 per claim on admin. Average practice processes 3,000-10,000 claims/year.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI processes claims, prior authorizations, and medical coding at $3-8 per claim vs. $20-40 current cost. Reduces prior auth time from 13 hours/week to <2 hours.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference per claim: $0.50-$1.50. Human review (10% exception rate): $1-3 per claim. Infrastructure: $0.50. Total: $2-5 per claim.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-claim processing fee or monthly subscription based on volume
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 2x (smaller practices currently skip proper coding/prior auth due to cost)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $200B+ (admin costs $1.3T, addressable portion ~$300B, 5x cost advantage, 2x Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: HIPAA compliance, EHR integration library, medical coding accuracy data, payer relationship database

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Clinical Capacity Multiplier for Nursing Teams
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Hospital systems and home health agencies facing nursing shortages. 6,000+ hospitals, 30K+ home health agencies in US.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles clinical documentation, triage, scheduling, and follow-up. Each AI system adds 20% capacity per nurse (Deloitte estimate). Equivalent to 600K additional nurses across US nursing workforce.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per nurse: $200-500/month. Integration: $50K-200K per hospital system. Total per nurse-equivalent: $300-600/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-nurse subscription + implementation fee
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x (enables service in underserved rural areas)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $50B+ (travel nursing $20B market + capacity expansion)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Clinical workflow integration, training data from usage, regulatory compliance track record, hospital system switching costs

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI-Augmented Primary Care for Underserved Markets
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Patients in primary care deserts (80M+ Americans in Health Professional Shortage Areas). Rural clinics, FQHCs, and telehealth-first practices.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles intake, screening, documentation, and follow-up. One physician + AI can serve 2x patient panel. Makes rural/underserved practice economically viable.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per patient per month: $5-10. Physician time (reduced by 40%): remaining cost. Total: enables practice profitability in areas where patient volume is too low for traditional model.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-patient-per-month subscription to clinics + outcome-based bonuses
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (80M+ Americans in HPSAs currently lack access)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $100B+ (primary care $300B market, 3x Jevons for underserved)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Clinical validation data, patient outcomes track record, regulatory compliance, data flywheel from patient interactions

unit_economics.cost_advantage_ratio: 5:1 to 10:1 for admin; 3:1 to 5:1 for capacity
assumptions: AI achieves 90%+ accuracy on medical coding
10% exception rate requiring human review
EHR integration feasible via standard APIs

evidence: Healthcare CPI above headline for 20+ years
cascade_position.timing_assessment: optimal — demographic urgency creates regulatory tailwind

incumbent_analysis.notes: Epic is adding AI features (sustaining innovation). But Epic serves large systems; 600K+ independent practices are underserved. The opportunity is the long tail, not the enterprise.

regulatory_landscape.acquisition_path: HIPAA compliance ($100K-200K setup). State-specific healthcare AI laws navigated per jurisdiction.
regulatory_landscape.regulatory_trajectory: fragmenting (47 states with bills = moat for first compliant entrant)
regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: Multi-state compliance is 12-18 months and $500K+ to replicate — strong first-mover moat

confirmed: Nursing shortage is real: HRSA data, 500K+ projected shortfall
Admin costs are 30%+ of healthcare spending: CMS data, ~$1.3T
Healthcare CPI above headline for 20+ years: FRED data
AI can do medical coding: multiple products in market achieving 90%+ accuracy
likely: Practices will pay per-claim for AI processing: cost savings are 5-10x, ROI clear
Hospital systems will pay for nursing capacity tools: travel nurse costs are extreme
Regulatory trajectory is toward acceptance: shortage creates necessity
uncertain: EHR integration difficulty: varies by system, testable with $50K pilot
Physician/nurse adoption rate: testable with 10-practice pilot
Liability framework for AI-assisted clinical decisions: evolving

barriers.resolution_path: $100K-200K compliance setup; once done, locks out underfunded competitors
Build integration library; each integration adds moat
Start with admin (non-clinical); expand to clinical after track record
Hire healthcare domain expert as first hire or advisory role

recommended_next_steps: Start with healthcare ADMIN (claims, prior auth, coding) — lower liability, clear unit economics
Build HIPAA-compliant infrastructure first ($100K-200K investment)
Pilot with 10-20 independent practices in California
Expand to clinical capacity tools after proving admin model
verdict.reasoning: Largest stored Baumol energy in the US economy ($1.3T in admin costs). Demographic urgency (500K+ nursing shortfall) creates regulatory tailwind. Admin model has clear 5-10x cost advantage. Start admin, expand clinical. Regulatory complexity is barrier-as-moat.

opportunities.structural_shift: Insurance: 400K worker attrition, 91% adopting AI, claims processing is routine-cognitive. Dead business revival — Lemonade thesis with better AI.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Claims Processing Service for TPAs and Mid-Market Insurers
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Third-Party Administrators (1,200+ in US) and mid-market insurers (property/casualty, health, auto) processing 10K-500K claims/year each.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: End-to-end AI claims processing: intake, document extraction, damage assessment, adjudication recommendation. $5-15 per claim vs. $30-80 current cost. Turnaround: hours vs. days.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference per claim: $1-3 (multimodal processing). Human adjuster review (15% exception rate): $3-8. Infrastructure: $1. Total: $5-12 per claim.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-claim processing fee
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x (enables faster, cheaper claims = higher customer satisfaction = more policies)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $40B+ (US P&C claims processing ~$30B, 5x cost advantage, 1.5x Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Claims data flywheel, payer integration network, state insurance compliance, accuracy track record

business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Spanish-first AI claims processing at 70-90% lower cost than manual processing. Bring developed-market claims technology to emerging market insurers.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference: $0.50-2 per claim. Local human oversight: $1-3. Total: $1.50-5 per claim.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-claim + platform licensing
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (many LATAM insurers currently process manually due to cost)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $15B+ (LATAM insurance market ~$80B, claims processing ~$10B addressable, 3x Jevons)

15% exception rate for human review
Multimodal AI achieves adequate damage assessment accuracy

regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: Multi-state compliance + model law readiness = strong first-mover moat

confirmed: Insurance workforce attrition: 400K by 2026 (BLS)
AI claims processing works: Avallon, Tractable, Sprout.ai proving it
Institutional readiness: Allianz launched agentic claims AI
likely: TPAs will pay per-claim for AI processing: ROI is 5-8x
LATAM market is receptive: weaker incumbents, manual processes

Start with simple claims (auto, property), expand to complex

Build multimodal claims processing (vision + NLU + structured data)
Pursue state compliance in 5 highest-volume states first
Develop LATAM version (Spanish) as expansion beachhead
verdict.reasoning: Insurance claims is the most validated AI service model in this cycle (Avallon 10x, Allianz launch). Demographic gap forces adoption. LATAM expansion leverages founder advantage. Per-claim revenue model aligns incentives.

opportunities.structural_shift: YC calling for AI-staffed law firms. Obelisk model replacing pyramid. Legal tech market doubling. First M&A expected 2026.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI-First Law Firm for SMB Corporate Legal
business_models_constructed.target_customer: SMBs ($1M-$50M revenue) spending $10K-100K/year on outside counsel for contracts, compliance, employment law, IP. 5M+ potential customers.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles contract drafting/review, compliance monitoring, entity formation, trademark filing at 70-80% lower cost. Human attorneys handle negotiation, litigation strategy, complex judgment.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per matter: $50-200 (vs. $2K-10K currently). Attorney oversight: $100-500 per matter. Total: $150-700 per matter.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly retainer ($500-5000/month) + per-matter fees for complex work
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x (most SMBs handle legal informally or skip it entirely)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $80B+ (US legal services ~$350B, SMB addressable ~$50B, 3x Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Bar-licensed operation, contract/precedent database, compliance track record, client relationship lock-in

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Legal Research & Drafting Platform for Solo/Small Firms
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Solo practitioners and small law firms (300K+ in US) who can't afford associates or paralegals. Average firm: 1-5 attorneys.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI paralegal that handles research, drafting, discovery, and document review. Each AI paralegal equivalent saves $60K-80K/year in associate cost.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per firm: $500-2000/month. Total platform cost: $15-30/user/month at scale.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly SaaS subscription per attorney
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 2x (enables solo practitioners to take on more complex work)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $20B+ (legal support staff market ~$15B, AI replacement + Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Legal precedent database, jurisdiction-specific training, accuracy track record, bar association relationships

10-15% exception rate for attorney review
Bar licensing navigable in target states

evidence: YC calling for AI law firms

incumbent_analysis.notes: Law firms are among the most structurally stuck incumbents: partner model, billable hours, leverage ratios. Harvey is well-funded but sells tools TO firms, not replacing them. LegalZoom targets consumers. Gap: AI-first full-service for SMBs.

regulatory_landscape.regulatory_trajectory: stable (bar associations protective but shortage forcing accommodation in some areas)

confirmed: Legal tech market growing 9%+ CAGR (verified market data)
YC explicitly backing AI law firms (YC RFS 2025)
AI can handle standard legal research and drafting: Harvey, CoCounsel proving it
likely: SMBs will pay $500-5K/month for AI legal retainer: savings are 5-15x
Solo practitioners will adopt AI paralegal: cost savings critical for small firms
uncertain: Bar association reaction to AI-first firms: state-by-state, testable
Malpractice insurance for AI-assisted legal work: evolving

barriers.resolution_path: Acquire small practice or partner with licensed attorney
Harvey sells to firms; gap is AI-first service to SMBs

recommended_next_steps: Identify bar licensing pathway in California
Build contract review + drafting MVP for common SMB legal needs
Partner with 2-3 licensed attorneys for oversight layer
Test with 20 SMB clients at $500-1500/month retainer
verdict.reasoning: Legal services has massive Baumol energy (decades of above-CPI inflation), huge Jevons expansion (most SMBs skip legal), and YC validation of the AI-first firm model. Bar licensing is the moat.

opportunities.structural_shift: PE roll-up Minsky moment: 30% of bankruptcies PE-backed, refinancing wall + AI margin compression creating double squeeze.

business_models_constructed.model_name: Distressed Professional Services Acquirer (AI-First Roll-Up)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Distressed PE-backed professional services firms (accounting, staffing, consulting, marketing agencies) with client books available at 0.3-0.5x revenue.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Acquire client relationships from distressed firms at fraction of historical cost. Serve those clients with AI-first cost structure at 50-70% of previous pricing. Clients get price reduction; we get 5-10x better margins than the incumbents had.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: Acquisition cost: $100K-500K per client book. AI service delivery: 10-20% of incumbent cost. Human oversight: 10-15% additional.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Recurring service revenue from acquired clients
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 1x (serving existing clients, not expanding market)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $25B+ (distressed professional services assets becoming available, $100B+ in PE-backed services revenue at risk)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Acquired client relationships, below-market acquisition cost, AI-first cost structure that PE roll-ups can't match

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI-First Staffing Platform
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Companies using temporary staffing agencies (market ~$180B in US). Staffing is a classic Baumol sector with high labor costs and PE roll-up concentration.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles candidate matching, credential verification, scheduling, and onboarding at 40-60% lower staffing markup. Current markup: 25-60%. AI-first: 10-25% markup.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per placement: $50-200. Human recruiter oversight: $100-300 per placement. vs. incumbent cost: $500-2000 per placement.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Reduced markup on hourly placement fees
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 2x (companies that currently avoid agencies due to markup will use lower-cost service)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $50B+ (US staffing $180B, addressable portion ~$80B, 2x Jevons at lower markup)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Candidate database and match quality data, employer relationship network, AI-driven screening accuracy

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: 1.5-2.5x revenue for client book; Staffing: $500-2000 per placement
assumptions: Distressed assets available at 0.3-0.5x revenue
Client retention rate 60-70% through acquisition
AI matching accuracy comparable to experienced recruiters

cascade_position.timing_assessment: optimal — distress is peaking, assets available

incumbent_analysis.notes: PE-backed firms are the most stuck: debt service requires revenue that AI is compressing. They literally cannot restructure without defaulting on debt.

regulatory_landscape.acquisition_path: Standard asset acquisition; some professional services require license transfer
regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: Acquired licenses from distressed firms are available at below-market prices

confirmed: PE bankruptcies rising: 30% of filings, up 15% YoY (Epiq)
Refinancing wall is real: 2020-2021 debt maturing 2025-2027
AI can deliver professional services at lower cost: multiple proof points
likely: Distressed assets will be available at discounted prices: follows from bankruptcy dynamics
Client retention through acquisition: 60-70% based on industry norms
uncertain: Deal flow access: need broker/banker relationships, testable with outreach
Speed of cascade: could accelerate or plateau

Build relationships with bankruptcy attorneys and business brokers

verdict.reasoning: The PE distress cascade is confirmed and accelerating. Distressed assets at 0.3-0.5x revenue + AI-first service delivery = extraordinary economics. The window is 12-24 months as the refinancing wall forces exits.

opportunities.structural_shift: AI regulatory fragmentation creating compliance maze — 47 states + EU + sector-specific. RegTech market growing 17-36% CAGR.

business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 10x+ (compliance was previously unaffordable for most companies; now required as AI regulation expands)

confirmed: AI regulation is fragmenting: 47 states, EU AI Act (verified)
Compliance gap exists: FINRA report, industry surveys
RegTech market growing 17-36% CAGR (multiple market reports)
likely: SMBs will pay for AI compliance: regulation forcing it
Regulatory complexity will increase: political momentum toward more regulation
uncertain: Federal preemption: possible federal AI law could simplify (and reduce demand)
Enforcement timeline: regulations exist but enforcement may lag

recommended_next_steps: Map all current state AI regulations into structured database

Test with 20 companies deploying AI in healthcare/insurance
Monitor federal AI legislation for preemption risk
verdict.reasoning: Regulatory fragmentation is a structural tailwind for compliance services. The barrier IS the moat — building multi-jurisdiction compliance expertise is expensive and time-consuming. Jevons expansion is massive: AI compliance was previously irrelevant for SMBs but new laws make it mandatory.

unit_economics.cost_advantage_ratio: 10:1 to 20:1 for platform; premium pricing for marketplace
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 5,000 trade business subscribers or 10,000 marketplace jobs/month
assumptions: Trade businesses will adopt digital tools
10-15 hours/week of admin genuinely recoverable
Premium positioning resonates with homeowners

cascade_position.timing_assessment: optimal — shortage worsening, tech adoption increasing in trades

incumbent_analysis.notes: ServiceTitan targets large shops ($1M+ revenue). Gap: solo operators and 2-5 person shops that can't afford $200-500/month platforms. Also: AI-native approach vs. adding AI features to existing SaaS.

confirmed: Skilled trades shortage is real and worsening: BLS data, 400K+ unfilled
Back-office is a major time sink: industry surveys, 20-30% of time
likely: Trade businesses will pay $99-299/month: comparable to existing tools
AI scheduling/dispatch achieves adequate quality: simpler than clinical/legal tasks
uncertain: Solo operator adoption rate: traditionally low tech adoption, but generational shift happening
Differentiation from ServiceTitan/Jobber: price point and AI-native approach may suffice

barriers.resolution_path: Target underserved segment (solo to 5-person shops) at lower price
Mobile-first, SMS-based interface; minimize complexity

recommended_next_steps: Interview 50 solo/small trade operators about admin pain points
Build SMS-first MVP for scheduling and invoicing
Test at $99/month with 100 trade businesses
Measure hours saved and willingness-to-pay
verdict.reasoning: Massive demographic gap in tacit-manual work + AI-automatable back-office = Baumol Premium opportunity. The human workers become MORE valuable; the platform captures the admin surplus. Lower moat than regulated sectors but higher adoption readiness.

opportunities.structural_shift: LATAM AI market 26% CAGR; 45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring; nearshoring creating cross-border service demand.

business_models_constructed.model_name: Bilingual AI Business Services for US-LATAM Companies
business_models_constructed.target_customer: US companies nearshoring operations to LATAM (est. 50K-100K companies) + LATAM companies serving US clients. Need bilingual compliance, HR, finance services.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI-powered bilingual (English/Spanish) business services: compliance, HR, payroll, tax across US-LATAM jurisdictions. $500-3000/month vs. $5K-20K for cross-border consulting.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per client: $50-150/month. Bilingual human review: $100-300/month. Total: $150-450/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription tiered by complexity and jurisdictions
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (many small companies nearshoring informally without proper compliance)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $25B+ (cross-border business services ~$10B, growing 20%+ annually, 3x Jevons)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Bilingual AI training, cross-border regulatory expertise, LATAM market knowledge, founder's Argentina background

business_models_constructed.model_name: LATAM AI-Services Marketplace (Agentic Delivery)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: LATAM businesses ($100K-$10M revenue) that can't afford professional services at US price points. 20M+ SMBs across LATAM.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Deliver US-quality accounting, legal, and compliance services in Spanish at LATAM price points using AI. $50-500/month.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per client: $10-30/month. Local human review: $20-50/month. Total: $30-80/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription in local currency
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 5-10x (vast majority of LATAM SMBs have no professional services)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $50B+ (LATAM SMB professional services market ~$20B, 5x Jevons expansion at AI prices)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Spanish-native AI, LATAM regulatory knowledge, first-mover in underserved market, local pricing

assumptions: AI handles 80% of cross-border compliance work
LATAM businesses will adopt cloud-based services
Payment processing works across LATAM currencies

evidence: 45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring

incumbent_analysis.notes: Deel/Remote focus on HR/payroll, not full business services. Big 4 serve enterprise only. Gap: AI-first full-service for SMBs operating cross-border.

regulatory_landscape.acquisition_path: N/A for platform; may need local licenses in specific LATAM countries
regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: Cross-border expertise is hard to build, creating natural moat

confirmed: Nearshoring trend is real: 45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring
LATAM AI market growing 26% CAGR (industry reports)
likely: Cross-border compliance demand will grow: follows from nearshoring
SMBs will pay for bilingual AI services: cost savings are 5-15x
uncertain: LATAM payment processing: varies by country, testable
LATAM SMB adoption rate for cloud services: growing but uneven

barriers.resolution_path: Differentiate with full-service (not just HR) and AI-first pricing
Start with Mexico + Argentina (largest markets with strongest founder connections)

recommended_next_steps: Interview 30 US companies nearshoring to LATAM about compliance pain
Build MVP for US-Mexico cross-border compliance
Price test at $500-1500/month with 10 pilot clients
Expand to Argentina, Brazil, Colombia in phase 2
verdict.reasoning: The nearshoring wave creates structural demand for cross-border business services. Founder fit is the strongest in the entire landscape: native Spanish, Argentina background, ML capability. The question is market timing and execution speed.

opportunities.structural_shift: Education Baumol cure: private tutoring only for wealthy 10-20%. AI at 10x lower cost unlocks 80% of market.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Tutoring for Underserved K-12 (US + LATAM)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Families earning $30K-$100K who want tutoring but can't afford $40-100/hr. 35M+ students in US, 100M+ in LATAM.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Personalized AI tutoring at $20-50/month. Adaptive, available 24/7, covers core subjects (math, science, SAT prep). Spanish and English.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per student: $3-8/month. Content/curriculum: $2-4/month amortized. Total: $5-12/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly family subscription or school district license
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 5-8x (80%+ of families currently can't afford tutoring)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $30B+ (tutoring ~$10B in US, 5x Jevons, LATAM expansion)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Student learning data, adaptive algorithm improvement, curriculum partnerships, bilingual content

assumptions: AI tutoring achieves measurable learning outcomes
Parents will pay $20-50/month for tutoring
Mobile-first works for target demographic

cascade_position.timing_assessment: early — market developing but not yet breaking

regulatory_landscape.compliance_as_advantage: COPPA/FERPA compliance for K-12 creates modest barrier

confirmed: 80%+ of families can't afford regular tutoring (industry data)
AI can provide effective tutoring for standard subjects (Khan Academy, Carnegie results)
likely: Parents will pay $20-50/month: aligns with streaming service psychology
uncertain: Learning outcome measurement: key for retention, testable in 3 months
School district sales cycle: potentially 6-12+ months

barriers.resolution_path: Differentiate with adaptive AI + Spanish-first for LATAM + outcome tracking
Rigorous A/B testing with outcome measurement

recommended_next_steps: Build MVP for SAT prep or math tutoring (measurable outcomes)
Test in LATAM market first (less competition from Khan Academy, Spanish advantage)
Measure learning outcomes rigorously for 3 months
Decide go/no-go based on outcome data + retention
verdict.reasoning: Massive Jevons expansion (80% of families priced out). But competitive landscape includes free alternatives (Khan Academy). Strongest angle: LATAM expansion (underserved, Spanish advantage, less competition). Economic force is real but moat is thin.

opportunities.structural_shift: 280x inference cost collapse enabling deployment-phase businesses. Perez turning point approaching.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Service Factory (Multi-Vertical Agent Builder)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: SMBs in various verticals that need AI-powered services but can't build them. Horizontal platform, vertical execution.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Deploy pre-built AI service agents for specific business functions (customer service, content, data analysis, operations) at $200-2000/month. Each agent replaces $3K-15K/month in human cost.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI inference per agent: $20-80/month. Customization: $50-200/month amortized. Total: $70-280/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription per agent deployed
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (businesses that couldn't afford these functions now can)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $100B+ (enterprise SaaS ~$200B transitioning to Service-as-Software)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Agent library, customization database, integration framework, usage data for improvement

assumptions: AI agents can reliably handle specific business functions
SMBs will pay $200-2000/month for agent services

evidence: 40% enterprise apps to embed agents by end 2026
AI startup shakeout forcing focus on viable models
cascade_position.timing_assessment: optimal — infrastructure overbuilt, application layer underbuilt

confirmed: Inference costs dropped 280x (Epoch AI data)
Gartner: 40% enterprise apps with agents by end 2026
likely: Agent accuracy sufficient for many business functions: improving rapidly
uncertain: Competitive dynamics in agent marketplace: fast-moving space
Customer acquisition cost for SMB agent services: testable

barriers.resolution_path: Focus on specific verticals where domain expertise creates defensibility
Human-in-the-loop for critical decisions; accuracy improves with usage data

recommended_next_steps: Pick 2-3 verticals where founders have domain access
Build agent framework + 5 specific agents
Test with 50 SMBs at $200-500/month
Measure retention and expansion revenue
verdict.reasoning: The infrastructure-to-application shift is the largest macro force in AI right now. Economic force is enormous ($100B+). But competitive density is high and moat is uncertain. Best if combined with a vertical focus (healthcare, legal, trades) rather than horizontal.

opportunities.structural_shift: 90-99% AI startup mortality creating acqui-hire and IP acquisition opportunities.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Startup Asset Acquirer (Talent + Models + Data)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Not customer-facing: acquire distressed AI startup assets (fine-tuned models, datasets, talent) at cents on the dollar. Redeploy into revenue-generating vertical services.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: Acquire AI IP and talent from failing startups at 5-20% of development cost. Combine assets to build vertical AI services with pre-trained capabilities.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: Acquisition: $50K-500K per asset. Integration: $50K-200K. vs. building from scratch: $500K-$5M.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Revenue from services built on acquired assets
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: N/A
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $10B+ (estimated value of distressed AI startup IP available 2026-2027)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Deal flow access, integration capability, accumulated IP portfolio

barriers.resolution_path: ML founder can evaluate technical quality
Start with talent acqui-hires; lower integration risk

recommended_next_steps: Monitor YC and funded startup failures in target verticals
Build relationships with VCs who will want to place failing portfolio company teams
Identify 5 target acquisition candidates
verdict.reasoning: The Perez shakeout creates a window for acquiring AI capabilities at distressed prices. Best used as a COMPLEMENT to a primary vertical business model, not as the primary strategy.

opportunities.structural_shift: Low-wage Baumol sectors (home care, childcare, social work) underexplored by AI startups. Large workforces, severe shortages, sparse competition.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Operations for Home Health Agencies
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Home health agencies (30K+ in US) managing 4.6M home health aides. Currently use paper-heavy processes. Average agency: 20-200 aides.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles scheduling, care plan documentation, compliance reporting (state/federal), and family communication. $10-25 per aide per month. Currently, agencies spend $50-150 per aide on admin overhead.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per aide: $3-8/month. Infrastructure: $2-4. Human oversight: $2-5. Total: $7-17/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Per-aide monthly subscription
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 2x (enables agencies to manage more aides with same admin staff, expanding service capacity)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $15B+ (home health admin ~$5B, 2x Jevons, growing 8%+ annually)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: State compliance database (50-state), CMS regulatory expertise, workflow integration with home health-specific EMRs

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI for Childcare Center Operations
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Childcare centers and family daycare providers (500K+ in US). Cost pressures extreme: staff costs rising, parents' ability to pay flat. Average center: 5-50 children.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: AI handles parent communication, billing, licensing compliance, curriculum planning, and staff scheduling. $50-200/month per center vs. 5-10 hours/week of director admin time.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI per center: $10-30/month. Infrastructure: $5-10. Total: $15-40/month.
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription per center
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x (enables directors to expand capacity by reducing admin burden)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $5B+ (childcare admin, growing due to regulatory expansion)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: State licensing compliance database, parent communication platform lock-in

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $50-150/aide admin overhead or $500-1000/month for director admin time
assumptions: Home health agencies will adopt digital tools (trend accelerating post-COVID)
Per-aide pricing works financially for agencies
Childcare directors willing to adopt new technology

evidence: Home health aide workforce 4.6M and growing
AI competition very sparse in these sectors
cascade_position.timing_assessment: early-optimal — underexplored territory with real structural forces

confirmed: Home health aide workforce large (4.6M) and growing (BLS)
Childcare costs rising faster than inflation (Education data)
AI competition sparse in low-wage sectors (market observation)
likely: Agencies will adopt at $10-25/aide: ROI is clear
Regulatory compliance is a pain point: CMS and state requirements increasing
uncertain: Tech adoption rate in low-wage sectors: improving but historically low
Willingness to pay at these price points: testable with $10K pilot

barriers.resolution_path: Mobile-first, minimal-friction interface; integrate with existing workflows
Ultra-low pricing ($10-25/aide); volume play

recommended_next_steps: Interview 30 home health agency owners about admin pain points
Build MVP for scheduling + compliance documentation
Test at $15/aide/month with 10 agencies
Measure time savings and adoption friction
verdict.reasoning: Low-wage Baumol sectors are the most underexplored territory in the AI economy. Competition is sparse because startups chase high-margin sectors (Dutch Disease/T9). But the workforce is massive (4.6M home health aides alone) and the structural forces (demographic gap, regulatory expansion) are just as strong as in healthcare or legal.

opportunities.structural_shift: Coasean firm shrinkage: 1-3 person AI teams replacing 10-50 person agencies.

business_models_constructed.model_name: AI Micro-Agency Toolkit (Enabling the Micro-Agency Model)
business_models_constructed.target_customer: Freelancers and consultants transitioning to AI micro-agencies. 60M+ freelancers in US; growing portion adopting AI tools to scale output.
business_models_constructed.value_proposition: All-in-one platform for running an AI micro-agency: client management, AI workflow orchestration, deliverable generation, billing. $99-299/month.
business_models_constructed.cost_structure: AI infrastructure per user: $20-40/month. Platform: $10-20. Total: $30-60/month.
business_models_constructed.cost_advantage_ratio: N/A (enabling tool, not direct service replacement)
business_models_constructed.revenue_model: Monthly subscription + percentage of AI inference consumed
business_models_constructed.jevons_multiplier: 3x (enables individuals to operate agencies, creating new supply)
business_models_constructed.economic_force: $10B+ (freelancer platform market ~$15B, growing rapidly)
business_models_constructed.moat_source: Workflow templates, integration ecosystem, client management data

barriers.barrier: Low barriers to entry = high competition
barriers.resolution_path: Focus on specific vertical (e.g., AI marketing agencies)
Build quality differentiation and client matching

recommended_next_steps: Survey 100 AI micro-agency operators about tool needs
Build MVP for one specific agency type (e.g., content marketing)
Test willingness-to-pay at $99/month
verdict.reasoning: Coasean shrinkage is real but this is a picks-and-shovels play in a low-moat market. The structural force (firm shrinkage) is confirmed but the competitive dynamics are unfavorable. Better as a feature of a larger platform than a standalone business.
